We opted to keep our swimsuits on but everybody else tended to go naked. - An extraordinary amount of towels provided for you in the room (in all sizes) - Complimentary Neutrogena toiletries - Japanese breakfast ($15) at Restaurant Taiko. Recommend the Grilled Fish (mackerel/salmon). Came with rice, miso soup, pickels, shredded turnips and hot tea. A tasty and light way to start your morning! - Free shuttle service (can arrange at the front desk) - Short drive to Makena's Landing (less than 15 min) which is the starting point for most kayaking tours - Efficient cleaning staff (our room was always cleaned by the time we got back to the room) - Friendly, helpful front desk/valet staff - Close to the airport (30 min drive) -------------------------- Cons: -------------------------- - No HBO - Pool looked a bit outdated - Parking spaces were made more for compact cars (we drove a Dodge Avenger) - A bit of a drive to get to the more "festive" areas of the island (Lahaina: 30-40 min) - Need to call a dive shop to book water activities since there are no water activity operations located directly on the beach (such as in the Caribbean). Most activities start early (7am) since the waters get too choppy the later it gets. Recommend booking thru the Maui Dive Shop (8 locations throughout Maui). They booked us on the 2.5hr Turtle Reef Intro Kayak/Snorkel Tour (thru South Pacific Kayak Tours) for $65. Had a great time (fun guide and all equipment was provided). Short drive from the hotel (about 15 min to Makena's Landing). - Food was expensive (Wailea tended to be the pricier part of the island) -------------------------- Tips: -------------------------- - Go to the Maui Clothing Outlet in Kihei to purchase a swimsuit (all suits were almost 50% off regular retail prices). - Buy your souvenirs from the General Store. Seem to have the lowest prices. - Do a zipline tour. We booked ours through the Skyline Eco Adventures (Haleakala Skyline Tour). Awesome guides (Don/Jimmy) who were able to even get me (the person most nervous) to do all the lines! About an hour scenic drive from the Diamond Resort. -------------------------- Restaurant Picks -------------------------- - Kihei Cafe (Breakfast/Brunch, Local cuisine) - Maalaea Waterfront Restaurant (ask for Mike to be your waiter) - Restaurant Taiko (amazing Japanese breakfast) -------------------------- Conclusion -------------------------- Would most definitely stay at the Diamond Resort again. Nothing better after a long day of water activities than to relax in their hot Japanese bathhouse spa. A truly great value!

Reviews.Title: “Comfortable rooms, professional service, excellent value”
Reviews.Author: superfila
Reviews.Content: Diamond Resort is located in Wailea in the same resort area as Four Seasons, Waldorf Astoria, Fairmont, etc. If you want a hotel directly on the beach, a mega resort, or fawning all over you service, this is not the place for you. On the other hand, if you want a ocean view, a convenient location in Wailea, a LARGE suite, all for an incredibly reasonable price, then Diamond is worth your consideration. Although it is not directly on the beach, Diamond is just uphill about 2 minutes drive from the beachfront hotels. This was such a non-issue for us, esp since I had a car and you probably will too. Besides, how convenient is a "beach front hotel" when your room is on the 20th floor, 2 elevator banks, and 10 walkways away from the actual beach. By the time "Beach Front Hotel Guy" gets to the 2nd elevator bank, "Diamond Resort Guy" is already on the beach. For your driving trouble (barely), you get a spacious and comfortable townhouse style room, approx 900 sq ft, excellent views (if you so choose), and a wonderfully quiet and secluded location in Wailea. Ok, first of all, the resort public spaces are all top notch, very pleasant to stroll around, garden like with waterfalls and bridges, very scenic. Now for the really important stuff. The rooms are townhouse style, two floors, two suites per floor. We stayed in a top floor partial ocean view (#214), we felt like it was probably pretty close to a full ocean view and were very happy with the view. As already mentioned, the rooms are quite big, probably about 900 sq ft, and the bed could fit you and your 4 girlfriends (or boyfriends) if you are into that kind of thing. If you're not quite Hugh Hefner-like, you and yours could sleep sideways for fun I guess. Kitchenette with mini fridge, stove, sink (no microwave). Living room separated from bedroom by sliding doors. Couch in the living room is very comfortable, there is a tatami (think Japanese floor bed) if you want to put two bodies on the ground in the living room. Balcony off living room has 2 lay down pool chairs, lots of room. Bedroom is connected directly to the walk-in tub/shower room (Japanese style) with a shower door separating the bedroom from the walk-in tub/shower room. Some people might find the Japanese style tub/shower strange, we didn't think it was terribly inconvenient, and actually it was convenient to have a fully enclosed bath/shower "room" to wash our snorkel gear and such. Bathroom sink is in a separate closed space next to the bath/shower and toilet is a separate closed space off the bathroom sink room in the European style. Ok, someone mentioned dated furniture... yes, I'd guess the furniture is maybe 5 years old. You won't mistake this place for a W in terms of style, but I think it was fine, the comfort of the bed, sofa, and the storage spaces were definitely above average. Cleanliness was very good throughout the room and hotel, not quite Four Seasons clean but definitely equally clean or better than your average Westin. TV has a DVD player. We did not have any noise problems, very quiet. Maid service is very prompt, we left at various times of the day, sometimes for just 45 minutes for a quick bite to eat. Invariably, when we came back, the room would be made. It's like the maids magically knew exactly when we would leave and come back. Outstanding. Had some maintenance issues with A/C, these things happen at some point to everyone, the important thing is they were very prompt to fix it. Requests to the front desk for towels, etc to be brought to the room delivered promptly. Hotel spa is free to access (services extra), fully nude in the Japanese style, my wife said it wasn't over the top luxurious, but nice. Location: Pretty convenient if you have a car. We found beach, local road and highway access to be very convenient. Wailea and nearby Kihei has lots of restaurants, shops, beaches, but If you insist on spending all your days in, say, Kapalua, then you should go stay there. Wailea is about 45-50 minutes drive to Kapalua. We went up there for a day, can't say it's any better/worse than Wailea.. actually, Wailea seems like the newer resort area between the two. Just a matter of personal preference I think. The price: room rate was a great value for Wailea. Try doing a search for Wailea properties and compare, we found the Diamond Resort rate was very competitive for what you get. An aside about the choosing full or partial ocean view: the hotel is up on a slope of the hill. There are other condo developments downhill from the hotel. So, you will see either the roof of a condo, or the roof of a hotel building downhill from you. However, being that it is a hill, and all the buildings in the area are 2 stories, the so-called "partial ocean view" rooms on the top floor seemed to be pretty darn close to full ocean view rooms. Don't whine if you are not satisfied with a "partial ocean view" because you can see a branch or a roof top... it is partial for a reason, I'm just saying that what makes it "partial" is pretty negligible. Hotel restaurants: Capische? in the Diamond Resort was the best meal we had in Maui, romantic, outstanding Northern Italian food, best truffle risotto I've had outside of N. Italy, all dishes equally outstanding. You must try. Didn't find any compelling reasons to try their Japanese restaurant. If you want Japanese, Sansei in Kihei has early bird special 50% off sushi, cooked foods, all kinds of Japanese... quite good. If you want to eat there, call Sansei and ask them about the early bird special. Ok, conclusion: I think this is one of the best bang for the buck places I've stayed at in a while. It's comfortable, large, the right price, in a great location, and service is consistently good (they consistently try their best, within reason). You can't beat this place for around $240 a night (April, Partial Ocean). I would go back again if I was in the Wailea area again.

Reviews.Title: “Secluded resort, decor a little outdated though”
Reviews.Author: onegaucho
Reviews.Content: Stayed there as part of a guest for a wedding so we got a good deal ($200/night). I guess since the regular rate is higher, my wife and I expected a little more for our money. Positives: Quiet and secluded. Staff is extremely customer friendly and helpful. Valets are very helpful and friendly as well. Self-parking is relatively easy to find as well. The restaurant is fantastic for both dinner (Capische?) and breakfast - the Japanese and American style breakfasts are fantastic - and a much better deal than the Four Seasons down the street. Negatives: The rooms are a bit out-dated. They had a very 80s feel to them. Not the cleanest of bathrooms and the furniture is a bit old. No microwave as well and the fridge is really small. We were also there with our 1 year old baby. The crib they provided wasn't very sturdy so we're glad we brought our pack and play. Would we return if we came back to Maui? For the breakfast, possibly. For the rooms, probably not. We saw some condos that our friends rented nearby (across the street) that were very clean and very spacious for the same price.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome value! Highly recommend!”
Reviews.Author: liliuokalani
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed only one night at this resort (we were hopping around all over the islands), but we felt it was the best value of our whole trip. We got it on Priceline for about $200 a night. The suite was HUGE! This resort caters to Japanese tourists and it had several funky Japanese touches, like a fancy commode with a heated seat and bidet, a complete tea set in the kitchenette, and a seperate shower & bathtub. It was immaculately clean (more than I can say about any other place we stayed, even when we were spending twice as much $.) It had the largest bed I have ever seen in my life -- somehow it was bigger than a king -- we could've fit a 200 pound man in between us and not been crowded. We got there late, so we didn't get a chance to use the pool, but it looked nice. We got free use of a Japanese-style spa, with seperate facilities for men & women (you have to get naked), and since we went at about 9:30 PM, we were the only people in there -- it was awesome. We went to dinner at the Japanese restaurant (Tamiko I think it was called?), which had excellent sushi but was very expensive. There is also a very popular, highly rated Italian restaurant called Capische? on the property. It was very quiet there at night, which was fine with us, but I'm not sure it's for people looking for a happening place. It was definitely one of the nicest places we stayed (out of 9 different hotels and B&B's) and the best value.

Reviews.Title: “Very pleasantly surprised”
Reviews.Author: GaryT770
Reviews.Content: We were very happy with our stay here. The room was quite large, with a nice bedroom (huge bed), living room, porch, full kitchen, and a nice big bathroom with one of the fancy Japanese toilets. Like other guests have mentioned, we saw very few other guests on the grounds, which were nice and green. The spa is well worth your time. I had the whole place to myself when I went, and the waterfall room is very nice. It is also very close to the beaches. It's about a 1 minute drive to public parking (which was surprisingly easy to find) right by the water. You can see the water from the resort, and you get some great sunsets. The front desk staff was also very nice. If anyone is worried that it caters to Japanese tourists and you'll feel out of place, there is nothing to worry about. The staff speak English, in most cases as their first language (as far as I could tell), and all the signs and stuff have both English and Japanese, so it was really no problem at all. All in all, we were very happy with our stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went here on our honeymoon and LOVED it! The room is so big and the kitchenette was an added bonus for re-heating leftovers and even making a small meal. They rent you cookware so you don't need to buy it. The hotel was very full but we never heard anyone and we rarely saw anyone. The spa was very nice and relaxing. Since this trip we have compared every hotel to this one since the price was amazing and so was the size. We will go back and stay here again. I suggest booking through hawaii.com though since we got the best deal there.

Reviews.Title: “A Gem of a Hotel!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel is awesome! My husband and I were experiencing some unneeded stress in LA, so we fled last minute to this hotel in search of a Japanese style spa. The place was booked, but we got one of their "handicapped rooms," meaning that the deep bath and toilet are in the same room. They are separated by a shower curtain instead of separated by walls in the traditional Japanese way. I love Japanese-type showers when you can sit on a small stool and scrub and shower your body BEFORE getting in the tub, so I would have liked to have the walls onto which I could splash the showerhead around, but it was still cool. I would bathe at the spa everyday anyway... The room is huge and cheap compared to the smaller rooms at hotels down by the beach. And the spa was very traditional.. with showers and a dry steam room. The men and women's spas are separate, again - very traditional and comfortable. The main tourists here are Japanese, which helped me relax, because Americans sometimes forget to wash themselves completely before getting into the public bath..(ech!). so that was nice. AND - not many people use the spa... so you will definitely get many many minutes of alone time in there. The room even has a kitchenette with tons of utensils and pots and pans and plates.. Supermarket- SAFEWAY in Kihei is open 24 hours and their oranges (2lbs for $1) are great. The fish there is pretty fresh, too. ROY's Kihei has AMAZING Hawaiian Seafood and good Maui steaks- that Hawaiian Restaurant is near the SAFEWAY in the Piikea Rd. Complex. The hotel also has a laundry room ($2.50 total to wash and dry one load of clothes). CLOSEST BEACH AND OTHER COOL RESTAURANTS: Park down at the free parking at POLO BEACH... It is a 1 minute drive down the hill - make a left at the 4 lane crossing (Makena Alanui?), and park. You can either hang out here - OR- Walk towards beach, then take a right and walk on the boardwalk through amazing gardens. Please head to the Grand Wailea's HUMU... restaurant for the AMAZING Ahi Tempura appetizer (open at night). The 4 Seasons has a great restaurant that is open AM to PM -- Right on the beach - great views (we saw whales breeching!) surrounded by their excellent pool/fountain. Another great beach is a 10-15 minute drive south - BIG BEACH on Makena. Really great. There are places to eat on the road, but the really good one is a roadside BBQ with a house behind it - that is open from 11ish-4ish it says. We got there at 3:22PM - and it was closed, but I hear the food at this little joint rocks. If you drive further south, you will go through Makena National Park - a sea of molten lava on all sides. Feels like you are on Mars! Other than that - the staff is very helpful and everyone here is very friendly and quiet. A GEM OF A HOTEL!!!

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic!!!! Best hotel value we've ever had!”
Reviews.Author: walrus007
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Diamond resort for 16 nights in November 2005. This was the best value for money we've ever had at on any vacation! The service is top notch, far beyond our expectations. The staff are very friendly, intelligent, and are always available at a moments notice. Lots of attention to detail, for example we would phone the front desk asking for our car in 5 minutes. The valet had our car waiting out front with the engine running, the top down and the radio re-tuned to a great local station. Our Alamo rental car was supplied with the inside of the windshield filthy, I called the front desk, 20 minutes later we went up to get the car, it was clean. We really appreciated the staff not hovering around expecting tips every time they looked at us. On more than one occasion I had to call them back to get their tip, even after they spent 10 minutes helping us unload groceries, driving us down to our room in the golf cart, and helping us put them away. We called asking for extra coffee supplies, the doorbell rang 90 seconds later, impressive considering this is a 17 acre resort with about 18 separate buildings. We were upgraded no charge to a top floor room with a 180 degree unobstructed ocean view including Kahoolawee and Molokini and many stunning sunsets and beautiful sunrises. We didn't really get a room, its more like a condo, a large bedroom with a truly massive bed, a large living room and dining area, a kitchenette with a built in Jenair stove top, and a good sized lanai (balcony) with loungers to enjoy the view. Birds literally ate out of hand on the lanai. Extra large beach towels are supplied in the room. A very well designed suite with many architectural details we liked, too much to list here. We paid about $200 a night, in other Wailea resorts with good service and smaller rooms you'll pay $300 to $400, sure they may be on the beach but the beaches are very crowded and by law are open to all anyway. We drove down the hill, a 1 minute trip, parked for free, walked along the sea walk through many big resorts such as the Grand Wailea and had full access to their over-crowded beaches and facilities. We quickly learned were to find an almost deserted beautiful beach with perfect gold sand, excellent snorkeling and swimming. It required a 5.5 minute drive from Diamond, the locals asked us not to tell anyone about the beach(we did not see any other tourists, actually we didn't see a lot of clothing on some people that we did meet!). We did not pay a resort fee, we did not get charged for dishes and cookware, we did not pay for valet or self park, we did not pay for computer and internet use in the library. We did not pay for the spa. They wanted $25 to use the gym, $50 with a trainer, it appears to be operated by a fitness chain, not the hotel, we skipped it. The spa is Japanese style. It has seperate sides for men and women so romance is out. You must be buck naked to go in, no clothing is allowed in the spa. That counted me out, I didn't go in. My wife went 3 times, theres usually only 2 or 3 people in it at a time. She has mixed feeling about it. Its well lit, so when you stand up in the sit and soak pool your bits and pieces are on display at eye level, not for everyone. Food: The Japanese restaurant is good but not excellent, we get better sushi in Vancouver for the same cost, its a bit open and noisy, not really a good choice for a romantic dinner but overall not bad. Le Gunji didn't exist when we were there, the patio bellow Capische was being renovated, maybe that has something to do with it. Capische has a nice setting with a great bar and really good live piano/bass entertainment. The service is excellent, all the staff was very attentive and friendly. The wine list is eye popping, many are $250 and up. Many hard to find top wines. The food was just plain awful. I had lamb shank on risotto with spring onions. The lamb was almost flavorless, like it had been rinsed under water after cooking (I really suspected it had). The risotto was so vinegary that I couldn't eat it, my wife tried it then went straight to her wine to kill the bitter taste. The spring onions were limp and wet and also tasted like they were boiled in vinegar. I don't know what happened - maybe some kind of kitchen accident? My wife had Ahi tuna, a very nice piece of meat, but the rest of the plate was disappointing. Desert was also very bad, the worst tiramisu we've ever had, usually one of our favorites. Out of 150+ fine dining experiences this is the worst food we've ever had, no question. We paid $200 for the two meals, one desert, 2 coffees(good) and $60 wine(the second from cheapest, excellent). The room food service is limited by time and choice. Breakfast is either Japanese or American, with limited options. We ordered one of each. The kitchen called to make sure we really wanted the Japanese, we should have taken the hint. DO NOT GET THE JAPANESE BREAKFAST!!! If a fish could be desert road kill it would look like this. The American style wasn't very good either. Two breakfasts were $39. There are dozens of dining opportunities near by, the hotel will shuttle you to any neighboring resort no charge. I believe the hotel is well aware of the restaurant issues and are working to improve them, we saw many hints of on going improvements, i.e. brand new chairs showed up at Capische half way through our stay. We generally don't eat more than once or twice at any hotel we stay at, we like to head out and experience the area, so the food issues had little impact on our rating. The kitchenette saved us at least $1000! Overall we were very happy and will be staying again next time we are in Maui. We were calling our suite "home" by the third day. Even after 16 days it was hard to leave. This resort is ideal for couples looking for a quite, relaxing, romantic stay. Families with kids needing constant entertainment may not like it here. Note that Wailea has a community association that keeps the area in pristine condition. Private security patrols the area constantly, including the hotel parking areas. We saw only one young "punk" driving too fast and squealing his tires, 2 security vehicles were on him in seconds and literally chased him out of town. I would not hesitate to walk the streets at night in Wailea. There is no graffiti or visible vandalism, no groups or gangs "hanging out" and virtually no litter. Maui was the best vacation we've ever had.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Having read somewhat negative reviews we were a bit taken aback to end up with the Diamond through HotWire. It was fortunate the hotel was chosen for us, as it turned out to be far more appropriate for our needs than the Fairmont and Four Seasons, the others we considered. The hotel: The villas are surrounded by park-like grounds filled with waterfalls, pools and koi ponds. One rarely sees other guests and the entire resort is extremely quiet and peaceful. This was a pleasant surprise compared to the resorts on the beach. The swimming pool is small, good for an evening dip for kids who can't get enough of the water. The spa is a wonderful touch that we used almost every day, and it was remarkable to me that so few people did. The sushi restaurant is quite good, the Italian restaurant is ok and has an excellent view. Breakfast in the hotel is mediocre: The front desk advised against it and recommended another restaurant at the Shops at Wailea instead, which turned out to be a very good restaurant. The front desk is extraordinarily helpful, very pleasant, and the bellhops provided service just as good. The hotel also has a library with a desktop computer, useful for taking care of business when necessary or for printing out boarding passes in advance. The suites: We had a room labelled "partial ocean view", perhaps because we could see only part of the Pacific Ocean--but there was nothing but Pacific Ocean to be seen from our lanai or from any of the windows in the suite. The suites are large, about 700-750 square feet with a large kitchen/living area, a very large bath/dressing/toilet/closet area (including a large sunken tub and Japanese toilet) and a good sized bedroom with the largest bed we've ever seen. The setup worked well for us: Our two small children slept on the fold-out couch and we had the bedroom. The kitchen is small but worked well for breakfast and for light dinners. We found that full dinners in restaurants didn't work for us because we and the kids were too tired, so used lunch as a break for the day and ate light dinners in our suite at night. Overall pluses: Quiet, uncrowded resort; beautifully landscaped grounds; spacious and quiet, comfortable suites; kitchenette in suites; great spa; excellent service; superb views of the ocean; good price; free parking. Overall minuses: Small pool (which wasn't a problem for us since we spent every day near the ocean and used the pool only at night).

Reviews.Title: “A BMW for the price of a Honda”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: First of all, I'd like to point out that this resort is not in Kihea, but in Wailea. Comparing Kihea to Wailea is like comparing Harlem to the Upper east side - so close, yet worlds apart. This resort is in an excellent location, perched up a hill with excellent ocean views. But this is NOT an oceanfront resort. So if like to walk out of you room and onto the beach or into a beautiful pool, this is not your resort. You could however, walk to the beach in about 10 minutes. What I loved most about this place is that the suites are huge - I'd say about 650 sq feet - and each building has only 4 bright, airy suites, giving the entire resort an open, luxurious feeling. I have to admit that at their rack rate of $350 a night, this resort is no steal. I stayed in a full oceanview suite for $200 a night. Do not book this resort online. Call them and ask for the $200 special (especially during off-season). This is a great deal considering that your neighbors at the Grand Wailea, Four Seasons, and the Fairmont are all paying around $500 a night. The spa onsite is top notch. So is the japanese/sushi restaurant. Take a raincheck on their pool and Italian restaurant. You are sorrounded by resorts with much better pools and restaurants. For the reviewers who gave this resort bad reviews because of a $4 charge for renting utensils and microwaves - all I have to say is you could save a lot more than 4 bucks if you stayed in Kihea.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I got married on the property and found it to be so, so beautiful and serene. A great place to go to get away from all of the tourism.

Reviews.Title: “The Diamond Resort”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: They were very helpful and informative. They reccommended restraunts and stuff to do in Hawaii. Helped us get a rental car.

Reviews.Title: “The Diamond was not the best”
Reviews.Author: hamburgerpanda
Reviews.Content: The main problem with the Diamond is that it is neither a resort that you don't need to leave ever, nor it is a condo with everything you need to be self-sufficient. This is a problem in Wailea where you're more or less dependent on your hotel. When we first checked in we loved the view and the balcony, and the place was huge. However we got tired of having to pay resort prices, but still had to drive down the hill to find an open restaurant or bar, or even go to the beach. The Japanese-style baths were cold and not relaxing. I have been to hot spring baths in Japan, and that is an inviting and invigorating experience. This was not. There is also a normal pool and hot tub, but they are only open until 6 pm! There are three restaurants: two Japanese, and one Italian. The Japanese-French one is not really haute cuisine like they make it sound. That's probably why the restaurant is almost always completely empty. The Italian restaurant is a little more lively, and we enjoyed having a drink at the outdoor bar there, but it doesn't stay open late like other bars in Maui. We didn't visit the third, because it was always closed. The condo has a Japanese-style shower-room and separate toilet room. These could have been cleaner, or updated. The kitchen was very small with a mini electric stove and no oven, no microwave, no dishwasher, no dish drainer. And you had to rent a set of pots that didn't include much. The refrigerator was tiny and filled with frost, and froze all our food, so we didn't cook very much in the room. The king bed really is two twins pushed together. I couldn't believe it. The employees were very nice, though it's true that not many spoke English well enough to give you tourism advice or directions. I think that's a primary function of any hotel and shouldn't be overlooked. The grounds are well kept and the sunsets are a glorious sight from your balcony. It's very quiet with no children and I appreciated that. But as we visited other Wailea resorts throughout the week, and sat on their beaches with tropical drinks, and ate at fun restaurants, and watched people relax on loungers at the pool all day, I couldn't help but feel that was the Maui experience we had wanted to have, and the Diamond was just lacking. My advice is either to pay more for a true Wailea resort on the beach, or stay in a friendly condo in laid-back Kihei.

HotelInfo.Name: Hotel Wailea
HotelInfo.Address: 555 Kaukahi Street, Wailea, Maui, HI 96753
